title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 1 july [1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 1 July [1868]
text: â€”1868July 1My dear Walti got your letter yesterday and the money order and magazine and two papers all very good it will last me some time to read i like to have something on hand to read although i cantcan't read as i once could i get sleepy and tired when i read of an evening but i like very much to have something to read)i am pretty well now as well if not better than i was last summer i dontdon't take any kind of medicine now only bathbathe my limbs with cold water) i had a letter from marthaMartha mondayMonday it was longer coming than it ought to have been but i got it the 29th it was about 4 days coming they are pretty well sis has got well of the chills and mattyMatty is well all but her coughfcough hasenthasn't quite left her yet but they seem to be taking their comfort in having company and going round matt says jeffJeff is very busy has hardly any time to himself she said she had wrote a long letter to hannHannah telling her everything that would interest her so han gets letter from all quarter squarters well walterWalter dear as every body asks every body how are you going to spend the 4th one year ago this fourth i was here with the boxes and barrels all piled up around me it dontdon't seem like a year since we moved here but time comes round and every year makes us one year older) last sundaySunday i went down stairs and something i scarcely ever doodo i opened the front door and stood looking out a few minutes and i saw an old man with three children crossing over from hamilton aveHamilton Ave.and they looked kind of nice so i waited till they crossed over the man kept looking at me i thought he wanted to inquire the way somewhe but lo and behold it was Bartlett and his family i didentdidn't know him at first he said his wife said the other day how bad it was they had lost the run of mrsMrs. Whitman well i mI'm in for it now he took down the number they were going up to prospect parkProspect Park he has as much as he can doodo he says in survayingsurveying he made 50 dollerdollar saturdaySaturday so if jeffJeff ever comes back he could get prenty of work georgeGeorge had to apply to several before he could get his lot survayedsurveyed theirthere is so much property bought and sold georgeGeorge has his cellar dug and the foundation began sometimes he gets quite fretty about his building thinks he wontwon't have money enoughfenough to finish it but i will tell you all about it when you come home which will be before long Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 1 July [1868]
